page.title: 07BIRD LIFE
page.content: The island on Belmont Reservoir is home to an ever-increasing flock of Canada Geese during the summer months. One pair, some 20 or more years ago arrived, probably attracted by food for domestic fowl; they have multiplied and now number over 100. They nest on the island but tend to feed elsewhere during the day, returning to roost at night, and their honking cries can be clearly heard. Also seen on the reservoir or its margins are mallard, teal, coots, moorhen, tufted ducks and shelducks, oyster catchers, heron, ringed plovers, goldeneye, pochard, sandpipers, curlews and gulls sheltering from gales at sea. The moors are the haunt of lapwings, snipe, redshank, crows, rooks, magpies, skylarks, meadowpipits, kestrels and even a pair of wheatears.
